senses.de: Easy to see or understand, clear
senses.ex: It's obvious that he doesn't like the plan.

Tips.title: Non-literal use
Tips.description: Sometimes 'obvious' is used to emphasize feelings, not just facts.
Tips.example: It's obvious to everyone that she's the best player.

Tips.title: Avoid overuse
Tips.description: Using 'obvious' too much can sound rude, as if you're talking down to someone.
Tips.example: She avoided saying it was obvious to not embarrass her friend.

Tips.title: Mismatched perception
Tips.description: What's obvious to you may not be to others, due to different knowledge or experiences.
Tips.example: While it was obvious to the teacher, the students were confused.

senses.de: Easy to recognize or identify, because it's against what is normal or usual
senses.ex: It's obvious that he is a foreigner.

Tips.title: Identifies uniqueness
Tips.description: 'Obvious' underscores a characteristic that makes something or someone stand out.
Tips.example: Her accent made it obvious she wasn't from around here.

Tips.title: Context sensitive
Tips.description: 'Obvious' can depend on context. What's obvious in one situation may not be in another.
Tips.example: To a mathematician, the solution is obvious; to others, maybe not.

Tips.title: Negative connotation
Tips.description: Describing someone as 'obviously' something can imply they don't fit in, use carefully.
Tips.example: He was obviously the new guy, unsure of where to sit.

senses.de: Predictable, lacking in subtlety or originality
senses.ex: The ending of the movie was too obvious.

Tips.title: Predictability
Tips.description: When events unfold as expected, 'obvious' describes the lack of surprise.
Tips.example: The thief took the obvious escape route, straight into the police's hands.

Tips.title: Creative criticism
Tips.description: In creative fields, 'obvious' might be used negatively to describe lack of originality.
Tips.example: The artist's work was criticized for its obvious lack of creativity.

Tips.title: Emotional tone
Tips.description: Use 'obvious' to convey frustration or sarcasm over something predictable.
Tips.example: He said with a sigh, it was obvious they would be late again.

Apparent.wordDefinition:
Apparent means that something may seem to be true, but it is not necessarily true. It is based on what is visible or known at the time, but there may be more information that could change the situation.

For example, it may be apparent that a student did not study for their test, but they may have other things going on in their life that affected their ability to prepare.

Apparent describes something that may seem to be true based on what we currently know or see, but there may be more information that could change the situation.

Clear.wordDefinition:
Clear means something that is easy to understand or see. It could mean that the information provided is concise and straightforward, making it easy to comprehend.

For example, "The instructions were clear and easy to follow."

Overall, both words refer to something that is easy to understand or see, but clear pertains to the presentation or explanation of information while obvious refers to the inherent nature of something that doesn't need to be explained.

Evident.wordDefinition:
The words evident and obvious both mean that something is easy to see or understand.

Evident implies that something is clear, but it may require some explanation or analysis to fully understand.

For example, it may be evident that climate change is occurring when looking at data on increasing global temperatures and extreme weather events, but it may require further research and understanding of the causes and effects to fully comprehend.

Obvious is applicable when something can be easily seen or understood without any further explanation, while evident is applicable when something is clear, but may require further analysis or explanation to fully comprehend.

Manifest.wordDefinition:
Manifest means something that is clear or evident, usually because it is easily observed or understood. It is something that is readily apparent to everyone.

A good example would be the sun, which is manifest to everyone who goes outside during the day.

Manifest describes something that is very clear and almost impossible to miss, while obvious describes something that is easy to notice but may require some level of attention or thought to recognize.

Palpable.wordDefinition:
Obvious means something that is easily seen or understood, while the word palpable means something that can be felt or perceived physically.

For example, if someone is wearing a bright red shirt, it is obvious to the eye. If someone has a fever, it is palpable because you can physically feel their hot skin.

Obvious describes things that are clear or easily noticed, while palpable describes things that are tangible or perceptible through touch or other physical senses.

Patent.wordDefinition:
Patent refers to something that is officially recognized as being an original invention or design and is protected by law.

For example, if someone invents a new type of phone case that has never been seen before, they can apply for a patent to protect their design and ensure that no one else can copy it without permission.

Obvious refers to something that is easily noticed or understood, while patent refers to something that is officially recognized as original and protected by law.

Plain.wordDefinition:
Plain refers to something that is simple or ordinary.

It is used for things that are not complicated or fancy. For example, a plain T-shirt doesn't have any decorations or patterns.

Obvious describes something that is clearly visible or understandable, while plain describes something that is simple or ordinary.

Transparent.wordDefinition:
Transparent means something that is easily seen through or understood. It usually refers to something that is clear, open or honest, such as a person or a process.

For example, it is obvious that the sun rises in the east and sets in the west, but a transparent government would make sure that its citizens know the reasons behind its decisions and policies.

Obvious refers to something that is easy to see or understand without much effort, while transparent refers to something that is openly visible or honest.

Unmistakable.wordDefinition:
Unmistakable means something that is impossible to confuse or misunderstand. It implies that the thing or concept is clear and unambiguous.

However, a stop sign is unmistakable because it is impossible to confuse it with anything else.

Obvious is applicable when something is easy to understand or see, while unmistakable is applicable when something is impossible to misinterpret or mistake for something else.

quotes.Text: Kids are born into the situation they're born into, and obviously, they have no control over that. And we, as adults, it's up to us to take care of kids - that's part of your moral responsibility. I always tell people, 'There's two groups we should take care of - old people and young people.
quotes.Title: American Baseball Player
quotes.Name: Charles Barkley

quotes.Text: I think that role model is kind of a weird thing because obviously you are, but I try to make good choices and good decisions for myself for me to have a good life. If that inspires someone else, that is great, but I think you should do good for yourself and your own happiness.

quotes.Name: Dakota Fanning

quotes.Text: It is obvious that we can no more explain a passion to a person who has never experienced it than we can explain light to the blind.
quotes.Title: American Poet
quotes.Name: T. S. Eliot

quotes.Text: Life has to be given a meaning because of the obvious fact that it has no meaning.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Henry Miller
